The ends of beams shall have not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm) of bearing on wood or metal and not less than 3 inches (76 mm) of bearing on concrete or masonry for the entire width of the beam. Where multiple-span beams bear on intermediate posts, each ply must have full bearing on the post in accordance with Figures R507.5.1(1) and R507.5.1(2).

Deck beams shall be attached to supports in a manner capable of transferring vertical loads and resisting horizontal displacement. Deck beam connections to wood posts shall be in accordance with Figures R507.5.1(1) and R507.5.1(2). Manufactured post-to-beam connectors shall be sized for the post and beam sizes. Bolts shall have washers under the head and nut.
children.displayTitle: R507.5.2 Deck Beam Connection to Supports

children.body: Maximum allowable spans for wood deck joists, as shown in Figure R507.6, shall be in accordance with Table R507.6. The maximum joist spacing shall be limited by the decking materials in accordance with Table R507.7. The maximum joist cantilever shall be limited to one-fourth of the joist span or the maximum cantilever length specified in Table R507.6, whichever is less.

diagrams.title: Deck Joist Lateral Restraint
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code requires that deck joists be provided with lateral restraint at their ends and at bearing locations. The restraint may be provided by blocking between the joists, a rim joist or joist hangers. Where blocking or joist hangers are used to provide lateral restraint the depth of the blocking or hanger must be at least 60% of the joist depth. Where a rim joist is used to provide lateral restraint each joist must be fastened to the rim joist with 3 or more 10d x 3" nails or 3 or more No. 10 x 3" long wood screws.

children.body: The ends of joists shall have not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm) of bearing on wood or metal and not less than 3 inches (76 mm) of bearing on concrete or masonry over its entire width. Joists bearing on top of a multiple-ply beam or ledger shall be fastened in accordance with Table R602.3(1). Joists bearing on top of a single-ply beam or ledger shall be attached by a mechanical connector. Joist framing into the side of a beam or ledger board shall be supported by approved joist hangers.

Joist ends and bearing locations shall be provided with lateral resistance to prevent rotation. Where lateral restraint is provided by joist hangers or blocking between joists, their depth shall equal not less than 60 percent of the joist depth. Where lateral restraint is provided by rim joists, they shall be secured to the end of each joist with not fewer than three 10d (3-inch by 0.128-inch) (76 mm by 3.3 mm) nails or three No. 10 x 3-inch (76 mm) long wood screws.

diagrams.title: Deck Joist Lateral Restraint
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code requires that deck joists be provided with lateral restraint at their ends and at bearing locations. The restraint may be provided by blocking between the joists, a rim joist or joist hangers. Where blocking or joist hangers are used to provide lateral restraint the depth of the blocking or hanger must be at least 60% of the joist depth. Where a rim joist is used to provide lateral restraint each joist must be fastened to the rim joist with 3 or more 10d x 3" nails or 3 or more No. 10 x 3" long wood screws.

children.body: Maximum allowable spacing for joists supporting decking shall be in accordance with Table R507.7. Wood decking shall be attached to each supporting member with not less than two 8d threaded nails or two No. 8 wood screws. Other approved decking or fastener systems shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation requirements.

diagrams.title: Decking: Wood or Plastic
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum allowable deck joist spacing is defined in Table 507.7 and depends on the type of deck joist being supported and the decking's orientation relative to its supporting joists. Where plastic composite decking is used the joist spacing is required to be per the manufacturers instructions.

children.body: Where supported by attachment to an exterior wall, decks shall be positively anchored to the primary structure and designed for both vertical and lateral loads. Such attachment shall not be accomplished by the use of toenails or nails subject to withdrawal. For decks with cantilevered framing members, connection to exterior walls or other framing members shall be designed and constructed to resist uplift resulting from the full live load specified in Table R301.5 acting on the cantilevered portion of the deck. Where positive connection to the primary building structure cannot be verified during inspection, decks shall be self-supporting.
Vertical and lateral supports for decks shall comply with this section.
children.displayTitle: R507.9 Vertical and Lateral Supports at Band Joist
children.titleText: Vertical and Lateral Supports at Band Joist

children.body: Vertical loads shall be transferred to band joists with ledgers in accordance with this section.

Deck ledgers shall be a minimum 2-inch by 8-inch (51 mm by 203 mm) nominal, pressure-preservative-treated Southern pine, incised pressure-preservative-treated hem-fir, or approved, naturally durable, No. 2 grade or better lumber. Deck ledgers shall not support concentrated loads from beams or girders. Deck ledgers shall not be supported on stone or masonry veneer.

diagrams.title: Deck Ledger and Band Joist Details
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where decks are supported on the primary structure by a ledger, the ledger must be at least a nominal 2x8, No 2 structural grade of pressure-treated Southern pine, pressure-treated hem-fir, or naturally durable lumber. When a stone or masonry veneer is below the ledger it shall not provide support to the ledger. Concentrated loads from deck beams or girders may not be supported by the ledger. Where the ledger is supported by a band joist, the band joist must bear fulling on the primary structure, typically a wall top plate. The band joist must be at least a solid nominal 2x of spruce-pine-fir or better, or 5/4x10 nominal lumber of Douglas fir or better, or a 5/4x10 nominal laminated veneer lumber.

children.body: Band joists supporting a ledger shall be a minimum 2-inch-nominal (51 mm), solid-sawn, spruce-pine-fir or better lumber or a minimum 1-inch by 9<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub>-inch (25 mm × 241 mm) dimensional, Douglas fir or better, laminated veneer lumber. Band joists shall bear fully on the primary structure capable of supporting all required loads.

diagrams.title: Deck Ledger and Band Joist Details
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where decks are supported on the primary structure by a ledger, the ledger must be at least a nominal 2x8, No 2 structural grade of pressure-treated Southern pine, pressure-treated hem-fir, or naturally durable lumber. When a stone or masonry veneer is below the ledger it shall not provide support to the ledger. Concentrated loads from deck beams or girders may not be supported by the ledger. Where the ledger is supported by a band joist, the band joist must bear fulling on the primary structure, typically a wall top plate. The band joist must be at least a solid nominal 2x of spruce-pine-fir or better, or 5/4x10 nominal lumber of Douglas fir or better, or a 5/4x10 nominal laminated veneer lumber.

children.body: Fasteners used in deck ledger connections in accordance with Table R507.9.1.3(1) shall be hot-dipped galvanized or stainless steel and shall be installed in accordance with Table R507.9.1.3(2) and Figures R507.9.1.3(1) and R507.9.1.3(2).

diagrams.title: Deck Ledger Flashing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where deck framing connects to a residence the deck ledger is required to be flashed. The flashing is required to prevent the water from reaching the band joist. The flashing must be lapped in a shingle fashion with the water-resistive barrier to prevent water from entering the wall cavity. Deck flashings material may be 0.019" minimum thickness corrosion-resistant sheet metal or an approved nonmetallic material compatible with the water-resistive barrier and decking materials.

children.displayTitle: R507.9.1.3 Ledger to Band Joist Details

children.body: Alternate framing configurations supporting a ledger constructed to meet the load requirements of Section R301.5 shall be permitted.

Lateral loads shall be transferred to the ground or to a structure capable of transmitting them to the ground. Where the lateral load connection is provided in accordance with Figure R507.9.2(1), hold-down tension devices shall be installed in not less than two locations per deck, within 24 inches (610 mm) of each end of the deck. Each device shall have an allowable stress design capacity of not less than 1,500 pounds (6672 N). Where the lateral load connections are provided in accordance with Figure R507.9.2(2), the hold-down tension devices shall be installed in not less than four locations per deck, and each device shall have an allowable stress design capacity of not less than 750 pounds (3336 N).

diagrams.title: Deck Ledger Flashing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where deck framing connects to a residence the deck ledger is required to be flashed. The flashing is required to prevent the water from reaching the band joist. The flashing must be lapped in a shingle fashion with the water-resistive barrier to prevent water from entering the wall cavity. Deck flashings material may be 0.019" minimum thickness corrosion-resistant sheet metal or an approved nonmetallic material compatible with the water-resistive barrier and decking materials.

diagrams.title: Lateral Load Path
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A lateral load path is a continuous sequence of structural elements in a building that is designed to safely transfer lateral forces, such as wind or seismic loads, from the point of origin to the supporting foundation system. This ensures the stability and safety of the structure under these forces.

Key aspects of a lateral load path include:
  • Designing structural elements to resist and transfer lateral loads
  • Designing wood-frame shear walls or wood-frame diaphragms to resist wind and seismic loads according to the American Wood Council's Special Design Provisions for Wind and Seismic
  • Designing masonry structures, including their connections, for lateral force-resisting systems in Seismic Design Categories
  • Considering the effects of torsion from eccentricity between the center of application of the lateral forces and the center of rigidity of the lateral force-resisting system
